author: @pdkovacs
text: Regarding "Bias and variance", I find these cross references in your videos really useful. The most difficult thing (to me) with these "small, very focused units with a limited scope" methodology (which you explained in a recent video so well...and, frankly, I cannot even imagine how teaching could be done meaningfully in any other way over this parcticular medium [perhaps the study guides are meant to compensate for this]) is that the connection between the small units easily gets lost and the big picture easily missed. Thank you for these shameless self-promotions! :-) And thank you for all the excellent content you create!

author: @Kingstanding23
text: Wrangling your own data is definitely the hardest part of machine learning. You watch a few videos and can recreate them, but when it comes to feeding in your own data, you suddenly realise, you don‚Äôt actually know anything. You can‚Äôt shape your data correctly, nor do you know if your new favourite ML algorithm is even applicable. What is needed, is to see someone faced with a completely new/unseen problem and dataset, and watch them go through the thought process and explain their rationale for choosing specific algorithms, how they go about shaping their data, and how they solve problems they face. This could be done using Kaggle on a live stream.
